description: From Middle English free, fre, freo, from Old English frēo (“free”), from Proto-West Germanic *frī, from Proto-Germanic *frijaz (“beloved, not in bondage”), from Proto-Indo-European *priHós (“dear, beloved”), from *preyH- (“to love, please”). Related to friend.

The verb comes from Middle English freen, freoȝen, from Old English frēon, frēoġan (“to free; make free”), from Proto-West Germanic *frijōn, from Proto-Germanic *frijōną, from Proto-Indo-European *preyH-.

adjectives.description: free (comparative freer or free-er or (rare) freeër, superlative freest or free-est or (rare) freeëst)

entries.meaning: Not imprisoned or enslaved.
Unconstrained by timidity or distrust
Generous; liberal.
examples: He's very free with his money.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Clear of offence or crime; guiltless; innocent.
Without obligations.
Thrown open, or made accessible, to all; to be enjoyed without limitations; unrestricted; not obstructed, engrossed, or appropriated; open; said of a thing to be possessed or enjoyed.
Not arbitrary or despotic; assuring liberty; defending individual rights against encroachment by any person or class; instituted by a free people; said of a government, institutions, etc.
(software) With no or only freedom-preserving limitations on distribution or modification.
(software) Intended for release, as opposed to a checked version.
(by extension, chiefly advertising slang) complimentary
examples: Buy a TV to get a free DVD player!

entries.meaning: (mathematics) Unconstrained by relators.
examples: the free group on three generators

entries.meaning: (mathematics, logic) Unconstrained by quantifiers.
examples:
z
      
    
    {\displaystyle z}
  
 is the free variable in 
  
    
      
        ∀
        x
        ∃
        y
        :
        x
        y
        =
        z
      
    
    {\displaystyle \forall x\exists y:xy=z}
  
.

entries.meaning: (programming) Unconstrained of identifiers, not bound.
(linguistics) (of a morpheme) That can be used by itself, unattached to another morpheme.
Unobstructed, without blockages.
Unattached or uncombined.
examples: Synonyms: loose, unfastened; see also Thesaurus:loose

entries.meaning: Not currently in use; not taken; unoccupied.
examples: You can sit on this chair; it's free.

entries.meaning: (botany, mycology) Not attached; loose.
examples: In this group of mushrooms, the gills are free.

entries.meaning: (military) Of a rocket or missile: not under the control of a guidance system after being launched.
Without; not containing (what is specified); exempt; clear; liberated.
examples: We had a wholesome, filling meal, free of meat.  I would like to live free from care in the mountains.

entries.meaning: (dated) Ready; eager; acting without spurring or whipping; spirited.
(dated) Invested with a particular freedom or franchise; enjoying certain immunities or privileges; admitted to special rights; followed by of.
(UK, law, obsolete) Certain or honourable; the opposite of base.
(law) Privileged or individual; the opposite of common.
examples: a free fishery;  a free warren

adverbs.description: free (comparative more free, superlative most free)

entries.meaning: Without needing to pay.
(obsolete) Freely; willingly.
(Australian rules football, Gaelic football) Abbreviation of free kick.
examples: Whether deserved or not, the free gave Cresswell the chance to cover himself in glory with a shot on goal after the siren.

entries.meaning: (soccer) A free transfer.
(hurling) The usual means of restarting play after a foul is committed, where the non-offending team restarts from where the foul was committed.
(swimming, informal) Abbreviation of freestyle.
examples: The team won the 200 meters free relay.

verbs.description: free (third-person singular simple present frees, present participle freeing, simple past and past participle freed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make free; set at liberty; release.
(transitive) To rid of something that confines or oppresses.
examples: Then I walked about, till I found on the further side, a great river of sweet water, running with a strong current; whereupon I called to mind the boat-raft I had made aforetime and said to myself, "Needs must I make another; haply I may free me from this strait. If I escape, I have my desire and I vow to Allah Almighty to forswear travel; and if I perish I shall be at peace and shall rest from toil and moil."

entries.meaning: (transitive, programming) To relinquish (previously allocated memory) to the system.
examples: There is no way to access that original area of memory, nor is there any way to free it before the program ends.
